Research Paper Swelling poly(ionic liquid)s supported silver N-heterocyclic carbene for efficient conversion of propargyl alcohols with CO2 Dandan Li Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization 1 Tong Lai Investigation Formal analysis Data curation 1 Jingshun Zhang Investigation Yang Hong Investigation Ziwang Zhang Investigation Guohua Gao Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Petroleum Molecular & Process Engineering, Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes, School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China Normal University, 3663 North Zhongshan Road, Shanghai 200062 Institute of Eco-Chongming, Shanghai 202162, China State Key Laboratory of Petroleum Molecular & Process Engineering, Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes, School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering East China Normal University 3663 North Zhongshan Road, Shanghai 200062 Institute of Eco-Chongming Shanghai 202162 China State Key Laboratory of Petroleum Molecular & Process Engineering, Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes, School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China Normal University, 3663 North Zhongshan Road, Shanghai 200062 Institute of Eco-Chongming, Shanghai 202162, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 Dandan. Li and Tong Lai contributed equally to this work. The conversion of propargyl alcohols and carbon dioxide (CO2) represents a hot spot in the field of CO2 utilization. In this study, a novel type of swelling poly(ionic liquid)s supported silver N-heterocyclic carbene (Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n) was designed and successfully synthesized through the free-radical copolymerization of silver N-heterocyclic carbene (Ag-NHC), 1-vinyl-3-butylimidazolium acetate ([VBIm]OAc) and the cross-linker N, N'-methylene bisacrylamide (MBA). The swelling behavior of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n in various solvents was investigated and the corresponding molar swelling ratios were determined as 314.6 mmol/g in water, 73.0 mmol/g in acetonitrile (CH3CN), and 56.8 mmol/g in 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol (1a). Notably, Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n exhibited a porous structure with a diameter of approximately ranging from 0.2 to 4 μm when swollen in CH3CN, effectively dispersing Ag-NHC moieties within the channels of the poly(ionic liquid) matrix. Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n were applied as catalysts for the carboxylative cyclization and hydration of propargylic alcohols in the absence of any homogeneous base additives. The catalysts achieved high yields (99 %) of 4,4-dimethyl-5-methylene-1,3-dioxolan-2-one (2a) and 3‑hydroxy-3-methyl-2-butanone (3a) by synergistically utilizing active sites provided by both silver (Ag-NHC) and base ([VBIm]OAc) moieties under mild conditions. Moreover, the catalysts could be reused six times without obvious loss in catalytic activity and had good substrate generality. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Swelling poly(ionic liquid)s Silver N-heterocyclic carbene Carbon dioxide utilization Propargylic alcohols Carboxylative cyclization Hydration Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Since the inception of fossil fuel utilization, there has been a gradual increase in atmospheric CO2 concentration. This increase is widely acknowledged as a primary driver for environmental issues, including global warming and the frequent occurrence of severe weather events [1]. The growing awareness of the severe consequences resulting from high levels of CO2 emissions has spurred advancements in technologies for CO2 utilization. Numerous reports have documented the conversion of CO2 into added-value products, such as syngas, methane, methanol (CH3OH), N, N-dimethylformamide, gasoline, dimethyl carbonate, and ethylene glycol [2,3]. However, the utilization of CO2 under mild conditions remains a significant challenge due to its exceptional thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertia. Among various methods for utilizing CO2, the carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols with CO2 is particularly noteworthy for its high atomic economic efficiency and broad industrial applications, including pharmaceutical chemistry, organic synthesis intermediates, lithium-ion battery electrolytes, and inert solvents [4–7]. Various catalysts, including metal complexes, organic acids and bases, bases/metals, ionic liquids, and electricity, had been developed with a remarkable selectivity for α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates [8–12]. Recently, the indirect hydration of propargyl alcohols in a CO2 atmosphere was also studied, which involved carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols with CO2 and hydrolysis of α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates. The hydration of propargyl alcohols holds great significance as the products, α‑hydroxy ketones, are crucial organic compounds extensively utilized in biological, pharmaceutical, and synthetic chemistry fields [13–17]. Consequently, significant efforts had recently been dedicated to developing efficient catalysts. Various homogeneous catalytic systems were developed including metal salts such as AgOAc [18] and Cu2O [19], ionic liquid [Bu4P][Im] [20], as well as metal salts/ionic liquids such as AgOAc/[Emim][OAc] [21], ZnO/[C4C1Im][OAc] [22], and CuSO4·5H2O/[C4C1Im][OAc] [23]. Furthermore, heterogeneous catalysts, namely silver-anchored porous aromatic framework catalyst (Ag@PAF-DAB) [24] and amino-functionalized organic polymer Ag@Co-PIL-NH2 [25] loaded with highly dispersed CuI were also reported. However, the catalytic activity of these heterogeneous catalysts relied on the addition of homogenous base additives, which might increase the complexity of the product separation and the recovery of these additives. Therefore, designing catalysts for efficient conversion of propargyl alcohols with CO2 that are free of homogenous base additives, easily recyclable, and reusable remains a significant challenge. Swelling poly(ionic liquid)s are organic polymers composed of repeat units of ionic liquids that exhibit exceptional swelling ability in specific solvents [26]. In recent years, swelling poly(ionic liquid)s have emerged as a novel material in the field of catalysis. Upon swelling, swelling poly(ionic liquid)s could form a porous structure, enhancing contact between the active sites and the reaction substrates. This behavior allows them to act quasi-homogeneously in solution and significantly increase catalytic activity [27–31]. Furthermore, the enrichment of substrates by swelling poly(ionic liquid)s could enhance the reaction rate and consequently increase the product yields [32]. Although swelling poly(ionic liquid)s have been successfully applied as heterogeneous catalysts for the hydrolysis/transesterification reactions of ethylene carbonate [33,34], the hydration of ethylene oxide and propylene epoxide, etc. [35,36], they have not been applied to the conversion of propargyl alcohols with CO2. In this study, a novel transition metal containing swelling poly(ionic liquid)s which were called swelling poly(ionic liquid)s supported silver N-heterocyclic carbines (Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n) were fabricated first time. The Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n catalysts demonstrated high efficiency in the carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols with CO2 and CO2-assisted hydration of propargylic alcohols under mild conditions in the absence of any homogeneous base additives. Additionally, Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n displayed excellent generality and recyclability. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n The swelling poly(ionic liquid)s supported silver N-heterocyclic carbene polymers were synthesized through the free-radical copolymerization of Ag-NHC, 1-vinyl-3-butylimidazolium acetate ([VBIm]OAc) and the cross-linker N, N'-methylene bisacrylamide (MBA). These polymers were designated as Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n, where n represented the molar ratio of [VBIm]OAc to Ag-NHC (Scheme 1 ). For comparison, both poly-silver N-heterocyclic carbine (P(Ag-NHC)) and poly(ionic liquid) (P(VBImOAc)) were synthesized by polymerizing Ag-NHC or [VBIm]OAc with MBA, respectively (Scheme S1). The structure of the synthesized swelling poly(ionic liquid)s supported silver N-heterocyclic carbene polymers was characterized by NMR spectroscopy, Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The 13C solid-state MAS NMR spectra of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n, P(Ag-NHC) and P(VBImOAc) and the 13C NMR spectrum of the monomers Ag-NHC and [VBIm]OAc were shown in Fig. 1 A. The signals at 104 and 108 ppm that corresponding to the vinyl group in Ag-NHC and [VBIm]OAc disappeared in the spectra of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n, P(Ag-NHC) and P(VBImOAc), indicating successful copolymerization between monomers and crosslinker [28]. A new signal at 40 ppm was assigned to the C atoms within the newly formed polymer chain. The presence of the peak at 175 ppm was attributed to the merging of carbonyl carbon of the acetate anion and carbene carbon of Ag-NHC. These phenomena supported the successful synthesis of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n. The FT-IR spectra of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n, P(Ag-NHC), and P(VBImOAc) were depicted in Fig. 1B. In the spectrum of P(VBImOAc), a peak at approximately 1155 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibration of the CN bond originating from the imidazolium rings. The intensity of this peak reduced in the spectrums of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n and P(Ag-NHC) due to the decrease of electron density on the imidazolium ring in resulted in Ag-NHC, which confirmed the successful incorporation of Ag-NHC [37,38]. The spectrums of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n and P(VBImOAc) exhibited a characteristic peak at 1569 cm−1 corresponding to the stretching vibration of the C = O bond of acetate, which confirmed the successful incorporation of OAc− [39]. These phenomena further supported the successful synthesis of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n. The thermal stability of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n, P(Ag-NHC) and P(VBImOAc) was investigated by TGA (Fig. 1C). A sight weight loss of these polymers below 190 °C was attributed to the removal of physically adsorbed water during heating. A significant weight loss observed in Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n, P(Ag-NHC) and P(VBImOAc) from 220 to 500 °C was consistent with the decomposition of imidazolium rings and carboxylic acid anion. In addition, the decomposition temperatures of these polymers progressively decreased with the increase of OAc− content due to the alkalinity of OAc− led to the degradation of imidazolium [40]. The above results demonstrated the exceptional thermal stability of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n, with a decomposition temperature exceeding 220 °C. The swelling ability was evaluated by the molar swelling ratio (QM) which was defined as the ratio of absorbed solvent moles to poly(ionic liquid)s in the dried state [32,36]. The Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−0.5 exhibited the high swelling ability in water (QM=314.6 mmol/g), CH3CN (QM=73.0 mmol/g), and 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol (1a) (QM=56.8 mmol/g) (Fig. 2 A). The microstructure of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−0.5 before and after swelling in CH3CN was examined by SEM and cryo-SEM. As depicted in Fig. 2B, the dry powder of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−0.5 consisted of micrometer-sized particles with nonporous structures. The element mapping images revealed a uniform distribution of C, N, O, Ag, and Br throughout the entire framework (Figure S1). Upon swelling in CH3CN followed by sublimation at −95 °C, Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−0.5 exhibited densely packed and interconnected pores ranging from 0.2 to 4 μm as observed through cryo-SEM analysis (Fig. 2C)[41]. The presence of abundant pores in Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−0.5 was attributed to the solvent molecules initially absorbed by polymer chains that replaced the original polymer-polymer interactions [28,42]. Importantly, these pores with varying sizes not only facilitated homogeneous dispersion of active sites for enhanced catalytic activity but also ensured the efficient mass transfer of reaction substrates [43,44]. 2.2 Carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols with CO2 catalyzed by Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n Initially, P(Ag-NHC) or P(VBImOAc) were used as catalysts alone, the carboxylative cyclization of 1a with CO2 gave low yields (1 % and 31 %) of 4,4-dimethyl-5-methylene-1,3-dioxolan-2-one (2a) (entries 1, 2, Table 1 ). However, when Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−0.5 containing Ag-NHC and the base group was used as a catalyst, the reaction proceeded smoothly and gave the desired product 2a in a yield of 71 % with only 1 mol % of catalysts (entry 3, Table 1). The enhanced catalytic activity of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−0.5 might be attributed to the synergistic effect between Ag-NHC and VBImOAc [45,46]. Subsequently, increasing the amount of catalyst to 3, and 7 mol %, the yield of 2a increased to 84 %, and >99 % (entries 4, 5, Table 1), presumably due to an increase in active sites within the reaction solution which facilitated an enhanced reaction rate [47]. Additionally, different ratios of Ag-NHC and [VBIm]OAc were tested using Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n (n = 1–3, and 6) resulting in yields for the product (2a) of 95 %, 94 %, 88 %, and 84 %, respectively (entries 6–9, Table 1). These results demonstrated that the synergistic effect between Ag-NHC and [VBIm]OAc might only be achieved at the appropriate ratio [48]. Furthermore, solvent effects on the reaction were also investigated. High polar aprotic solvents such as methyl sulfoxide (DMSO), and N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) resulted in good yields for the product (87 %, 81 %), while a medium polar aprotic solvent tetrahydrofuran (THF) afforded lower yields of 47 %, and protic solvents like CH3OH only resulted in yields of 4 % (entries 10–13, Table 1). The significant difference might be attributed to hydroxyl groups present within the solvent affecting recognition and activation by propargylic alcohol hydroxyl groups through interaction with the catalyst [49,50]. Furthermore, when different organic bases were also screened for the reaction, Ag-NHC@P(4VP)−0.5, and Ag-NHC @ P(VIM)−0.5 produced excellent yields of 99 % and 97 % for 2a, respectively. It was worth noting that the homogeneous VBImOAc/Ag-NHC catalyst afforded a relatively lower yield of 2a yield (88 %) compared to the Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−0.5 catalyst (entries 5, 16, Table 1). The superior catalytic activity of heterogeneous catalysts might be attributed to the enrichment ability of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−0.5 due to its capacity to swell in reaction substrates [28,30]. Additionally, compared with other heterogeneous catalysts, the Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n catalysts demonstrated high efficiency in the carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols with CO2 in the absence of any homogeneous base additives (Table S1). Encouraged by the remarkable catalytic performance exhibited by Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−0.5 in promoting the carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols with CO2, the substrate's scope was further investigated (Fig. 3 ). Under optimized reaction conditions (Figure S2), 3-ethyl-1-pentyn-3-ol (1b), 3-methyl-1-pentyn-3-ol (1c), 3,4-dimethyl-1-pentyn-3-ol (1d) and 3,5-dimethyl-1-hexyn-3-ol (1e) provided the desired products of 4,4‑diethyl-5-methylene-1,3-dioxolan-2-one (2b), 4-ethyl-4-methyl-5-methylene-1,3-dioxolan-2-one (2c), and 4-methyl-5-methylene-4-(1-methyl ethyl)−1,3-dioxolan-2-one (2d) and 4-methyl-5-methylene-4-(2-methylpropyl)−1,3-dioxolan-2-one (2e) in high yields of 99, 98, 98 and 99 %, respectively. The cyclic substituents 1-ethynylcyclopentanol (1f), 1-ethynylcyclohexanol (1g) and 2-phenyl-3-butyn-2-ol (1h) were also successfully transformed into the desired products of 4-methylene-1,3-dioxaspiro[4.4]nonan-2-one (2f), 4-methylene-1,3-dioxaspiro[4.5]decan-2-one (2g) and 4-methylene-5-phenyl-1,3-dioxolan-2-one (2h) in the yields of 99, 99, 52 %, respectively. These results collectively demonstrated that Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−0.5 served as an efficient catalyst for the carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols with CO2. The reusability of the catalyst was also tested. Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−0.5 could be reused at least seven times without an obvious decrease in catalytic performance (Figure S3A). In addition, the recycled catalyst did not show significant differences (Figure S3B-D) in MAS 13C NMR, FT-IR, and TGA spectra with the fresh one, indicating that the structure of the catalyst did not change in reaction. Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) analysis did not find silver elements in the reaction solution (<0.01 ppm), indicating that Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−0.5 maintained its integrity within the reaction system. 2.3 CO2-assisted hydration of propargylic alcohols catalyzed by Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n Recently, conducted studies demonstrated the capability of propargylic alcohols to undergo hydration with H2O in a CO2 atmosphere. The formed products, α‑hydroxy ketones, had diverse applications in fine chemical industries as organic intermediates [16,21–24]. In this part, Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n catalysts were employed for the hydration of propargylic alcohols in a CO2 atmosphere. Initially, the catalytic performance of various catalysts and atmospheres was investigated for the hydration of 1a (Table 2 ). When P(VBImOAc) was used as a catalyst, the reaction had a relatively low yield of 3‑hydroxy-3-methyl-2-butanone (3a) (10 %) with no detection of 2a, possibly due to the limited catalytic activity of P(VBImOAc) towards carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols (entry 1, Table 2). The use of P(Ag-NHC) without the base group as a catalyst resulted in only a moderate yield (30 %) of 3a, while a significant amount of 2a (60 %) remained (entry 2, Table 2). P(Ag-NHC) demonstrated a pronounced catalytic performance in the carboxylated cyclization of 1a. However, its hydrolysis activity of 2a was relatively low in the absence of base groups, which was consistent with previous studies [18,20,21]. Notably, the utilization of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−1 as a catalyst led to a significantly enhanced yield of 3a (70 %), accompanied by a decreased yield of 2a (27 %) (entry 3, Table 2). The Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−1 combined the catalytic active centers of Ag-NHC and [VBIm]OAc, exhibiting a synergetic effect for the CO2-assisted hydration of 1a [20]. When employing Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−3, the reaction achieved an impressive yield of 90 % for 3a and 2 % for 2a. (entry 4, Table 2). The catalytic activity of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n was found to be positively influenced by an increase in the base group [VBIm]OAc, indicating its crucial role in activating the hydroxyl groups of propargylic alcohols [20,23,51]. Upon increasing the amount of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−3 catalyst to 5 mol %, a maximum yield of 99 % was attained for 3a, while no detection occurred for 2a (entry 5, Table 2). The yield of 3a increase was consistent with that of a 2a decrease, suggesting the conversion from 2a to 3a. This transformation implied that the hydrolysis of 2a was also involved in the reaction [23]. Subsequently, the impact of CO2 pressure on the hydration of propargylic alcohols was investigated. When reducing CO2 pressure to 0.5 MPa, the yields were observed as 78 % for 3a and 4 % for 2a. (entry 6, Table 2). In the absence of CO2 in the system, no conversion of 1a was observed (entry 7, Table 2). Importantly, these results highlighted the remarkable sensitivity of hydration reaction towards variations in CO2 pressure [20,51]. By employing an H2O/1a ratio of 1.5:1 in this reaction system, a high yield (97 %) of 3a was achieved (entry 8, Table 2). Furthermore, by further reducing the stoichiometric H2O/1a ratio to 1:1, a high yield of 3a (95 %) could also be obtained (entry 9, Table 2). The catalytic performance in this study was comparable to that of the reported homogeneous catalysts with a significant excess of H2O [18,20,52]. The observed phenomenon might be attributed to the enhanced H2O enrichment ability of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−3, which was facilitated by its swelling capacity in reaction substrates [29,31,33,53]. Among the solvents investigated, CH3CN emerged as the optimal choice for facilitating the formation of the desired product. Specifically, methyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) exhibited lower yields of 75 % and 70 %, respectively, while dichloromethane(CH2Cl2) failed to promote product formation (entries 10–12, Table 2) [19]. The homogeneous [VBIm]OAc/Ag-NHC catalyst displayed an impressive yield of 99 % for 3a under identical reaction conditions, which was equivalent to the yield achieved by the heterogeneous Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−3 catalyst (entries 5, 13, Table 2). The exceptional performance of the current heterogeneous catalytic system could be attributed to the remarkable swelling capacity of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−3 in the reaction substrates [20,31,33,51,54]. Additionally, compared with other heterogeneous catalysts, the Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n catalysts demonstrated high efficiency in the CO2-assisted hydration of propargylic alcohols in the absence of any homogeneous base additives (Table S2). The detection of 2a in the CO2-assisted reactions suggested the potential involvement of CO2, leading to carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols with CO2 catalyzed by Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n [25,53]. The existence and transformation of 2a were further confirmed by monitoring its concentration at different times under optimized reaction conditions. As shown in Fig. 4 A, a considerable amount of 2a (38 %) was observed at the beginning, while its concentration gradually decreased to 14 % within 3 h and completely disappeared after 6 h, accompanied by an increase of the 3a yield. These findings suggested a one-pot two-step reaction pathway for the synthesis of 3a (Fig. 4B), which involved initial carboxylative cyclization of 1a with CO2 to generate intermediate 2a, followed by subsequent in situ hydrolysis leading to the formation of 3a and the concurrent release of CO2. Apart from the Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n catalysts, CO2 was also not consumed, which might be regarded as a promoting reagent or a co-catalyst for the hydration of 1a. To validate the proposed reaction pathway, isotope labeling experiments were conducted using isotope-labeled water (H2 18O), and the products were analyzed via GC–MS. The hydration of 1a with H2 18O under a CO2 atmosphere predominantly gave unlabeled 3a ((m-1)/z = 101), while 18O was transferred from H2 18O to C18OO (Fig. 4C) [55]. Similarly, the hydrolysis of 2a with H2 18O also generated unlabeled 3a ((m-1)/z = 101) as the main product, while 18O was transferred from H2 18O to C18OO (Fig. 4D). These results further confirmed the one-pot two-step reaction pathway for the synthesis of α‑hydroxy ketones by CO2-assisted hydration of propargylic alcohols [20,25,56]. Accordingly, a possible reaction mechanism was proposed (Figure S4). Initially, the hydroxyl protons and CC bond in propargylic alcohols were synergistically activated by Ag-NHC and OAc−, facilitating the formation of an intermediate (I). The linear CO2 then reacted with the intermediate, followed by intramolecular ring closure to form α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates while releasing the catalyst (cycle 1). Subsequently, water activated by OAc− through hydrogen-bond interaction attacked the carbonyl carbon of α-alkylidene cyclic carbonate, resulting in the ring opening and generating α‑hydroxy ketones along with CO2 while regenerating the catalyst (cycle 2). Encouraged by the remarkable catalytic performance exhibited by Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−3 in promoting the CO2-assisted hydration between propargylic alcohols and H2O, the substrates scope was further investigated (Fig. 5 ). Under optimized reaction conditions (Figure. S5), 1b, 1c, 1d and 1e afforded the desired products of 3-ethyl-3‑hydroxy-2-pentanone (3b), 3‑hydroxy-3-methyl-2-pentanone (3c), 3‑hydroxy-3,4-dimethyl-2-pentanone (3d) and 3‑hydroxy-3,5-dimethyl-2-hexanone (3e) in high yields of 92, 97, 76 and 95 %, respectively. The cyclic substituents 1f and 1g were also successfully transformed into the desired products of 1-(1-hydroxycyclopentyl)ethenone (3f) and 1-(1-hydroxycyclohexyl)ethenone (3g), respectively, exhibiting a remarkable yield of >99 %. These results collectively demonstrated that Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−3 served as an efficient catalyst for the CO2-assisted hydration of propargylic alcohols. The reusability of the catalyst was also tested. Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−3 could be reused at least seven times without an obvious decrease in catalytic activity (Figure S6A). In addition, the recycled catalyst did not show significant differences (Figure S6B, C) in FT-IR, and TGA with the fresh one, and no leaching of Ag was observed detecting by ICP-OES analysis (<0.01 ppm). These results indicated that the structure of the catalyst did not change in reaction. 3 Conclusions In conclusion, a series of swelling poly(ionic liquid)s supported silver carbene materials Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n were successfully synthesized through the copolymerization of silver carbine (Ag-NHC), ionic liquid [VBIm]OAc, and cross-linker. Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n had excellent swelling ability in water, CH3CN, and 1a. Moreover, Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n swellen in CH3CN exhibited an obviously interconnected pore structure, and Ag-NHC species were highly dispersed on the surface of swelling poly(ionic liquid)s. This exceptional swellable capacity enabled Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n to effectively combine the active sites of Ag-NHC and [VBIm]OAc, resulting in outstanding synergistic catalytic activity for carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols with CO2 and CO2-assisted hydration of propargylic alcohols in the absence of any homogeneous base additives. Mechanism investigations revealed that CO2-assisted hydration of propargylic alcohols catalyzed by Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n followed a one-pot two-step reaction pathway involving carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols with CO2 and hydrolysis of α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates. During the reaction, CO2 acted as a promoting reagent or co-catalyst which participated in the reaction but was not consumed. Additionally, Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n exhibited excellent generality and recyclability. 4 Experimental section The materials, characterization, and synthesis of the ionic liquid monomer [VBIm]OAc, silver carbene complex Ag-NHC, and Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n were provided in Supporting Information (SI). 4.1 Typical procedure for carboxylative cyclization of propargylic alcohols In a typical experiment, the 1a (0.210 g, 2.5 mmol), VBImOAc (2.5 mL), and Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−0.5 (0.0907 g, 0.175 mmol) were added into the autoclave and pressurized with CO2 (1.0 MPa). The reaction was stirred at 40 °C for 12 h. After the reaction was complete, the autoclave was cooled in an ice-water bath followed by slow venting of the CO2. The reaction mixture was analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) (GC-2014, Shimadzu, Japan), with a DM-1701 (30 m × 0.53 mm × 1.0 μm) capillary column and a flame ionization detector (FID), and biphenyl was used as the internal standard. Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−0.5 were deswelling in acetone and separated by simple filtration. The recovered catalyst was dried overnight at 80 °C for the next run. 4.2 Typical procedure for hydration of propargylic alcohols In a typical experiment, 1a (0.210 g, 2.5 mmol), water (0.079 g, 4.38 mmol), acetonitrile (CH3CN) (2.5 mL), and Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−0.3 (0.1460 g, 0.125 mmol) were added into the autoclave and pressurized with CO2 (1.5 MPa). The reaction mixture was stirred at 110 °C for 6 h. After the reaction was complete, the autoclave was cooled in an ice-water bath followed by slow venting of the CO2. The reaction mixture was analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) (GC-2014, Shimadzu, Japan), with a DM-1701 (30 m × 0.53 mm × 1.0 μm) capillary column and a flame ionization detector (FID), and biphenyl was used as the internal standard. Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)−3 were deswelling in acetone and separated by simple filtration. The recovered catalyst was dried overnight at 80 °C for the next run. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of propargyl alcohols and carbon dioxide (CO2) represents a hot spot in the field of CO2 utilization. In this study, a novel type of swelling poly(ionic liquid)s supported silver N-heterocyclic carbene (Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n) was designed and successfully synthesized through the free-radical copolymerization of silver N-heterocyclic carbene (Ag-NHC), 1-vinyl-3-butylimidazolium acetate ([VBIm]OAc) and the cross-linker N, N'-methylene bisacrylamide (MBA). The swelling behavior of Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n in various solvents was investigated and the corresponding molar swelling ratios were determined as 314.6 mmol/g in water, 73.0 mmol/g in acetonitrile (CH3CN), and 56.8 mmol/g in 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol (1a). Notably, Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n exhibited a porous structure with a diameter of approximately ranging from 0.2 to 4 μm when swollen in CH3CN, effectively dispersing Ag-NHC moieties within the channels of the poly(ionic liquid) matrix. Ag-NHC@P(VBImOAc)-n were applied as catalysts for the carboxylative cyclization and hydration of propargylic alcohols in the absence of any homogeneous base additives. The catalysts achieved high yields (99 %) of 4,4-dimethyl-5-methylene-1,3-dioxolan-2-one (2a) and 3‑hydroxy-3-methyl-2-butanone (3a) by synergistically utilizing active sites provided by both silver (Ag-NHC) and base ([VBIm]OAc) moieties under mild conditions. Moreover, the catalysts could be reused six times without obvious loss in catalytic activity and had good substrate generality.
